titleText.ttltext: Adjuvant therapy for advanced renal cell carcinoma

organizations: Department of Urology, The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Locally advanced, non-metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is conventionally managed with surgery. However, patients are at a high risk of RCC recurrence and have poor survival outcomes. An effective adjuvant systemic treatment is needed to improve on these outcomes. Targeted molecular and immune-based therapies have been investigated, or are under investigation, but their role in this setting remains unclear. Areas covered: A comprehensive search of @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and ClinicalTrials.gov was performed for relevant literature. The following topics pertinent to adjuvant therapy in RCC were evaluated: strategies for patient selection, cytokine-based immunotherapy, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end therapy, VEGF and non-VEGF targeted molecular agents, and immune checkpoint inhibitors. Expert commentary: Strong evidence for the incorporation of adjuvant therapy in high-risk RCC is lacking. Multiple targeted molecular therapies have been examined with only one approved for use. Genetic and molecular-based prognostic models are needed to determine who may benefit from adjuvant therapy. Developing adjuvant therapy strategies in the future depends on the results of important ongoing trials with immunotherapy and targeted agents.

titleText.ttltext: Cellular immunotherapy as a therapeutic approach in multiple myeloma

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Immunotherapy seeks to restore and augment the unique ability of the immune system to recognize and kill malignant cells. This strategy has previously been incorporated into standard of care in myeloma with the use of immunomodulatory drugs and allogeneic transplant. The following review will discuss the rationale for immunotherapy to reverse critical aspects of the immunosuppressive milieu in myeloma and avenues where cellular therapies are now revolutionizing myeloma treatment. Areas covered: A particular focus is outcomes of clinical trials in myeloma published in @hit_startPubMed@hit_end database or abstract form using @hit_startvaccines@hit_end or adoptive cell transfer: marrow infiltrating lymphocytes, T-cell receptor and chimeric antigen receptor T cells. Expert commentary: Immunotherapy has extraordinary potential in myeloma. Combinations of cellular therapies with immunomodulatory molecules or checkpoint inhibitors are likely to be synergistic and now underway. Future directions include neoantigen or nanoparticle @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and further modifications of engineered T cells such as use of dual-antigens, suicide genes or allogeneic cells.

titleText.ttltext: Effectiveness and safety of dual influenza and pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end versus separate administration or no @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in older adults: a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Guangdong Medical University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Background: The advantages of dual pneumococcal and influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in older adults have not been clarified and controversy remains regarding their optimal use. Methods: This @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was conducted on 25 January 2018 using @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, and @hit_startEmbase@hit_end databases. Seventeen studies were selected ultimately for @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end using a multi-step approach by two separate authors. Primary outcomes were pneumonia, pneumococcal pneumonia, influenza, hospitalization, and all-cause mortality rates, and the secondary outcome was adverse effects (AEs). Results: The additive preventive effects of dual inﬂuenza and pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end versus inﬂuenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end alone for pneumonia and death were 15% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 4-24%) and 19% (95% CI: 6-30%), respectively. Compared with pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end alone, dual influenza and pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end resulted in a 24% (95% CI: 16-31%) reduction in pneumonia and a 28% (95% CI: 13-40%) reduction in death. Compared with placebo or no @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, the effectiveness of dual @hit_startvaccination@hit_end was 29% (95% CI: 14-42%) for pneumonia, 38% (95% CI: 25-49%) for death, 35% (95% CI: 22-46%) for influenza, and 18% (95% CI: 6-29%) for hospitalization. Both @hit_startvaccines@hit_end showed acceptable safety profiles and AEs were mild or moderate. Conclusion: Our findings highlight the importance of concomitant influenza and pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in older adults.

organizations: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

paras: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end acceptance depends on public trust and confidence in the safety and efficacy of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and @hit_startimmunization@hit_end, the health system, healthcare professionals and the wider @hit_startvaccine@hit_end research community. This @hit_startsystematic review analyses@hit_end the current breadth and depth of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end research literature that explicitly refers to the concept of trust within their stated aims or research questions. After duplicates were removed, 19,643 articles were screened by title and abstract. Of these 2,779 were screened by full text, 35 of which were included in the final @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. These studies examined a range of trust relationships as they pertain to @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, including trust in healthcare professionals, the health system, the government, and friends and family members. Three studies examined generalized trust. Findings indicated that trust is often referred to implicitly (19/35), rather than explicitly examined in the context of a formal definition or discussion of the existing literature on trust in a health context. Within the quantitative research @hit_startanalysed@hit_end, trust was commonly measured with a single-item measure (9/25). Only two studies used validated multi-item measures of trust. Three studies examined changes in trust, either following an intervention or over the course of a pandemic. The findings of this review indicate a disconnect between the current @hit_startvaccine@hit_end hesitancy research and the wider health-related trust literature, a dearth in research on trust in low and middle-income settings, a need for studies on how trust levels change over time and investigations on how resilience to trust-eroding information can be built into a trustworthy health system.

titleText.ttltext: Community-acquired bacterial pneumonia in adult HIV-infected patients

organizations: Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Hospital Clinic of Barcelona

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Despite active antiretroviral therapy (ART), community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality among human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected patients and incurs high health costs. Areas covered: This article reviews the most recent publications on bacterial CAP in the HIV-infected population, focusing on epidemiology, prognostic factors, microbial etiology, therapy, and prevention. The data discussed here were mainly obtained from a non-@hit_startsystematic review@hit_end using @hit_startMedline@hit_end, and references from relevant articles. Expert commentary: HIV-infected patients are more susceptible to bacterial CAP. Although ART improves their immune response and has reduced CAP incidence, these patients continue to present increased risk of pneumonia in part because they show altered @hit_startimmunity@hit_end and because immune activation persists. The risk of CAP in HIV-infected patients and the probability of polymicrobial or atypical infections are inversely associated with the CD4 cell count. Mortality in HIV-infected patients with CAP ranges from 6% to 15% but in well-controlled HIV-infected patients on ART the mortality is low and similar to that seen in HIV-negative individuals. @hit_startVaccination@hit_end and smoking cessation are the two most important preventive strategies for bacterial CAP in well-controlled HIV-infected patients on ART.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end of the clinical development of group B streptococcus serotype-specific capsular polysaccharide-based @hit_startvaccines@hit_end

organizations: Faculty of Health Sciences, University of the Witwatersrand

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: @hit_startVaccination@hit_end against group B Streptococcus (GBS) during pregnancy could provide protection against disease in the mother, fetus, and newborn. @hit_startImmunity@hit_end through transplacental acquired antibodies in the newborns could persist through early infancy, reducing the risk of early-onset (<7 days age) and late-onset (7–89 days age) disease. We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of clinical trials on GBS capsular polysaccharide (CPS) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end to assess its safety and immunogenicity in pregnant and nonpregnant adults. Areas covered: We searched literature databases @hit_startPubMed@hit_end (@hit_startMedline@hit_end), Scopus, and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end library and identified 25 unique records on GBS CPS @hit_startvaccines@hit_end with or without conjugant protein. Expert commentary: GBS @hit_startvaccines@hit_end were well tolerated, with mild local reactogenicity being the main solicited adverse event and no difference in reporting of other serious adverse events compared to placebo recipients. CPS @hit_startvaccines@hit_end conjugated to immunogenic proteins induced ≥fourfold increase of serotype-specific antibodies with high longevity (1–2 years); and capable of promoting homotypic GBS opsonophagocytic killing. Feto-maternal transplacental antibody ratio of serotype-specific IgG ranged between 0.49 and 0.81. The clinical relevance of these immunogenicity studies, however, need to be weighed against a correlate of protection against invasive GBS disease in infants, which is yet to be established using a universally accepted standardized assay.

titleText.ttltext: Emerging antibacterial and antiviral drugs for treating respiratory tract infections

organizations: Department of Pathophysiology and Transplantation, Università degli Studi di Milano, Internal Medicine Department, Respiratory Unit and Regional Adult Cystic Fibrosis Center, IRCCS Fondazione Cà Granda Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Management of LRTI is becoming more frequently challenging since the emergence of multidrug resistance bacteria and the increase of severe viral infection, reducing the number of available effective drugs. The clinical evaluation of new therapeutic associations is mandatory to cope with the increases in resistance, in association with better infection control and antimicrobial policies. Areas covered: We searched @hit_startPubmed@hit_end in English language of phase I, II, III clinical trials and approved treatments for LRTI, between 2006 and 2016. Expert opinion:Development of new molecules or new combinations regimens are very important for patients with severe infections and in specific subgroups of patients like CF and bronchiectatic patients. Standardized protocols for antibiotic stewardship in difficult-to-treat infections are the next step. Moreover, non-antibiotic treatments and preventive strategies as @hit_startvaccination@hit_end need to be part of clinical practice.

titleText.ttltext: Does @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in solid-organ transplant recipients result in adverse immunologic sequelae? A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Nephrology, Monash Medical Centre

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 International Society for the Heart and Lung Transplantation
paras: Background: Clinical guidelines recommend @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end for solid-organ transplant recipients. However, concern exists that @hit_startvaccination@hit_end may stimulate adverse alloimmune responses. Methods: We @hit_startsystematically reviewed@hit_end the published @hit_startliterature@hit_end regarding this aspect of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end safety. Electronic databases were searched for interventional and observational studies assessing de novo donor-specific antibodies (DSA) and rejection episodes after @hit_startvaccination@hit_end against infectious pathogens. Graft loss was also assessed. A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was conducted for prospective, controlled studies. PRISMA reporting guidelines were followed. Results: Ninety studies (15,645 @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end patients and 42,924 control patients) were included. Twelve studies included control groups. The incidence of de novo DSA (14 studies) was 23 of 1,244 patients (1.85%) at 21 to 94 days. The incidence of rejection (83 studies) was 107 episodes in 5,116 patients (2.1%) at 0.7 to 6 months. @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of prospective controlled studies (n = 8) showed no increased rejection risk with @hit_startvaccination@hit_end compared with no @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (RR 1.12, 95% CI 0.75 to 1.70). This finding was supported by data from 3 registry @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. Conclusions: Although the current evidence lacks high-quality, controlled studies, the currently available data provide reassurance that clinicians should recommend appropriate @hit_startvaccination@hit_end for their transplant patients as the risk of de novo DSA and rejection is relatively low.

sourceTitle: Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation

titleText.ttltext: Ensuring childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end among slums dwellers under the National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program in India - Challenges and opportunities

paras: Aims: Almost, one third of the world's urban population resides in slums and the number would double by 2030. Slums denotes collection of people from various communities having a meagre income and living in unhygienic conditions thus making themselves most vulnerable for outbreaks of communicable diseases. India contributes substantially to the global disease burden and under-five mortality rates i.e. 20% attributable to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end preventable diseases. @hit_startImmunization@hit_end plays a crucial role in combating high childhood mortality rates attributable to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end preventable diseases across the globe. This @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end, provides insights on @hit_startimmunization@hit_end status in slums, identifies various factors influencing it thus, exploring opportunities that may be available to improve @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage under the National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program. Methods: Taking into account the above aspects, a @hit_startreview@hit_end of @hit_startliterature@hit_end was undertaken in various databases that included studies published between 2006 and 2017. Results: In India, ~33% of the urban population lives in slums with suboptimal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage ranging from 14% to upto 90%. Few of the important causes for low coverage included socioeconomic factors such as poor community participation, lack of awareness, frequent migration, and loss of daily income. Hence, mere presence of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in the National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program doesn't do the job, there is a definite unmet need to emphasize upon the importance of @hit_startimmunization@hit_end among slums dwellers and take necessary steps. For instance, delivering @hit_startimmunization@hit_end services at the doorstep (e.g. pulse polio program), community-based education, text messaging as reminders and incentivized @hit_startimmunization@hit_end services are some of the opportunities that can be explored and implemented to improve @hit_startimmunization@hit_end status in the slums. Conclusion: Thus, in addition to inclusion of more and more @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in the National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program, there is a definite need to focus on people living in high risk areas in order to improve coverage and healthcare indicators.

titleText.ttltext: Incidence of invasive pneumococcal disease in immunocompromised patients: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Infectious Diseases, Academic Medical Center, University of Amsterdam

paras: Background: Invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD) is associated with high morbidity and mortality, with immunocompromised patients (ICPs) at particular risk. Therefore, guidelines recommend pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end for these patients. However, guidelines are scarcely underpinned with references to incidence studies of IPD in this population. This, potentially results in unawareness of the importance of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and low @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rates. The objective of this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was to assess the incidence of IPD in ICPs. Methods: We systematically searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and @hit_startEmbase@hit_end to identify studies in English published before December 6th, 2017 that included terms related to ‘incidence’ ‘rate’ ‘pneumococcal’ ‘pneumoniae’ ‘meningitis’ ‘septicemia’ or ‘bacteremia’. We focused on patients with HIV, transplantation and chronic inflammatory diseases. Results: We included 45 studies in the @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end reporting an incidence or rate of IPD, defined as isolation of Streptococcus pneumoniae from a normally sterile site. Random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of 38 studies showed a pooled IPD incidence of 331/100,000 person years in patients with HIV in the late-antiretroviral treatment era in non-African countries, and 318/100,000 in African countries; 696 and 812/100,000 in patients who underwent an autologous or allogeneic stem cell transplantation, respectively; 465/100,000 in patients with a solid organ transplantation; and 65/100,000 in patients with chronic inflammatory diseases. In healthy control cohorts, the pooled incidence was 10/100,000. Discussion: ICPs are at increased risk of contracting IPD, especially those with HIV, and those who underwent transplantation. Based on our findings, we recommend pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in immunocompromised patients. Prospero registration: ID: CRD42016048438.
